executive_summary: Property managers are hired to oversee operations for apartment complexes and other rental sites. Demand for management services is countercyclical, as more consumers switch to rentals when the economy worsens and the price of home ownership increases. Managers experienced growth during the economic downturn brought on by COVID-19, carried by improved residential occupancy rates.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rental vacancy rates declined as property owners needed to fill more apartments to maximize revenue during a time of uncertainty, as the eviction moratorium prevented them from pushing out renters who couldn't pay. A sharp increase in office rental vacancies did pressure the industry, as working from home became the norm because of pandemic-related restrictions.
Revenue has grown at a CAGR of 1.4% to $117.3 billion over the past five years, despite a decline of 3.6% in 2023 alone.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Office rental vacancy rates will fall moving forward as the strict need for remote work has ceased. Nonetheless, some businesses will still allow employees to continue their work-from-home arrangements. The value of the properties will continue to grow in line with demand, allowing renters to charge higher rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic decline will push residents back to rentals
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite increasing disposable income, higher interest rates will likely lead to a decline in business activity and the value of disposable income. These detrimental conditions will lead to economic decline, pricing many consumers out of homeownership. Although an increase in renting will boost demand for property managers, corporations will suffer somewhat from the drop in business activity. This will limit growth moving forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Large developers will continue acquiring properties
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Organizations, including hedge funds and property developers, will continue buying up as many properties as possible. As economic conditions improve, more properties will be occupied, pushing down vacancy rates and boosting demand for property managers. As large developers invest more in diverse properties, the need for skilled property managers will grow.

Property technology (PropTech) innovations will continue to reshape the property management industry by introducing automated processes and digital solutions to improve tenant experience and minimize operational costs. These advancements will increase demand for tech-savvy property managers who can harness these tools.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manage residential and nonresidential real estate for property owners. Property management responsibilities relate to the overall operation of a property, including maintenance, rent collection, trash removal, security and some renovation activities. Industry players may also help manage a property's accounting, but operations related to the transactions of properties or real estate investments are not included in this industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Office rental vacancy

key_trends: Differentiation between property managers is minimal in the industry. Competition hinges on providing the most organized service with the highest customer satisfaction.
Reputation development is essential to securing contracts with large complexes. Companies with a history of high-quality, effective service rise to the front of owners' lists.
Property value determines the success of property managers. The greater the returns owners manage, the greater the need for managers.
The high cost of homeownership keeps consumers renting. Rising interest rates and darkening economic prospects prevent many from affording homes.
Small management operations make up most of the industry. Demand from small, independent rental facilities creates a highly fragmented industry.
Relationships with large companies lead to extensive contracts. The largest management companies fight to secure contracts with the most lucrative complexes.
Vacancies are directly tied to industry success. Although having some vacancies is essential to preserving property value, too many empty rentals lessen the need for managers.

Compliance with legislation is essential to success. Ensuring that managers themselves are compliant while also keeping property owners on the right side of the law helps develop a positive reputation.
Profit hinges on the success of rentals. When the rental market is healthy, more is spent on management services. boosting revenue.
Top-notch labor is essential. Workers who can successfully organize complexes and provide high-quality customer service are necessary for a property management company to stay afloat.
Cities continue to be home to the highest population of renters. Large apartment complexes provide a substantial portion of revenue for managers.
Population centers are home to the highest portion of business activity. Commercial properties in areas with the highest population require the most management.
Residential properties provide the greatest return for owners. The high number of residents necessitates extensive management to meet all needs.
The end of COVID-related disruptions brings back returns from commercial rentals. Offices are being repopulated while business activity has rebounded.

market_segmentation.segment_description: A residential property is a type of real estate that is primarily used for residential purposes, providing housing and living accommodations for individuals and families. Management services are essential here, as the sheer quantity of tenants makes it virtually impossible for property owners to handle things themselves.

Owners of commercial properties like offices and storefronts have enjoyed some growth in recent years, as corporations are bringing their employees back to work and growing per capita disposable income has led to increased business activity. Commercial property managers handle a different set of problems than residential, coordinating the construction of improvements and maintenance of high-traffic businesses.

products_and_services.product_description: Residential Properties Occupy the Majority of Managers. A residential property is a type of real estate that is primarily used for residential purposes, providing housing and living accommodations for individuals and families. As owners continue to stock up on as many properties as possible, extensive management service is required to address resident concerns to maintain

The Need for Commercial Property Management is Back on the Rise. A commercial property is a type of real estate that is primarily used for conducting business or commercial activities. As the economy improved in recent years, businesses have sought to expand, creating demand for storefront rentals which require management. As COVID-19-related restrictions have gone by the wayside, companies are increasingly bringing their employees back into the office, significantly decreasing office rental vacancies and raising the need for management services.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Real Estate Agent and Brokerage Services

products_and_services.product_description: The image appears to be a pie chart or donut chart showing the percentage breakdown of different types of properties or services related to property management. The largest segment, taking up 73.5% of the chart, is not labeled but likely represents the majority category of residential property management services. The other two labeled segments are: 1. Real Estate Agent and Brokerage Services at 20.1% 2. Other at 6.4%. The data suggests that residential property management makes up the bulk of the property management industry, with real estate agent/brokerage services being the second largest segment, and a small percentage of other miscellaneous services.

tier_2_suppliers: Heating & Air Conditioning Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Storage & Warehouse Leasing in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US
Accommodation and Food Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: As corporate profit increases, demand for rental spaces to conduct business grows, creating need for property managers.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Corporations often own many rental complexes, so when they perform better, they will invest more into improving their services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: CONSTRUCTION AND FACILITIES MANAGEMENT OPEN THE DOOR FOR PROPERTY MANAGERS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Other services property managers provide include facilities and construction management. By helping owners through the nitty gritty of getting properties in good enough shape to rent, managers develop key relationships which open the door for future business partnerships.

business_locations.location_description: Several cities in the West, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and Phoenix, have high population densities. This results in a greater demand for rental properties and, consequently, property management services. The West region often attracts real estate investors because of its potential for appreciation and rental income. Property managers may choose to be close to these investment opportunities to serve the needs of property owners seeking to capitalize on the West's real estate market.

The Southeast is home to the highest percentage of the United States population of any region. Since a growing number of consumers are stuck renting instead of purchasing their own homes, various types of rental properties need management, especially as large firms acquire as many properties as they can manage.

The Mid-Atlantic region, which includes states like New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, and Washington, D.C., is known for its relatively high population density. This results in a constant demand for housing, both residential and commercial, leading to opportunities for property management services. As the country continues to normalize following the end of pandemic-related disruptions, cities are again gaining popularity. This leads to high levels of construction of large apartment complexes, necessitating extensive management.

regulations_points.regulation_title: PROPERTY MANAGERS MUST REMAIN COMPLIANT TO OPERATE
regulations_points.regulation_description: Property managers are required to obtain licenses, abide by prescribed fiduciary responsibilities and adhere to antifraud prohibitions. Compliance with these prerequisites is the first step toward developing a positive reputation and securing business.

Property managers are tasked with ensuring their properties comply with real estate regulations, including zoning ordinances and licensing requirements. Ensuring owners do not violate renters' rights is another basic and essential service, which includes compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Housing Amendment Act.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
Low to steady industry assistance level.

basis_points.basis_description: Differentiation between property managers is minimal in the industry. Competition hinges on providing the most organized service with the highest customer satisfaction.
Reputation development is essential to securing contracts with large complexes. Companies with a history of high-quality, effective service rise to the front of owners' lists.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Local Real Estate Markets Drive Fragmentation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Real estate markets are highly localized, and property management is often tied to specific geographic areas.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Property Managers Handle Diverse Property Types
concentration_points.concentration_description: The property management industry covers various property types, including residential, commercial, industrial, and vacation rentals. Each property type has unique requirements, regulations, and market dynamics, leading to specialization in different segments and further fragmentation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Property Managers are Highly Reliant on Skilled Labor
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Property managers are essential customer service workers, so capable and friendly employees are essential to maintaining a positive reputation. Companies must spend on securing the best workers so they can handle the often-chaotic business of keeping a rental facility running smoothly.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Hinges on the Success of Renters
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As property owners' operations grow, so does their ability to spend and their need for management services. The greater the number of facilities managed, the higher the profit managers turn, as a few experienced and well-trained employees can smoothly scale to large complexes.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Reputation is Essential to Securing Business
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Property managers seek to develop reputations by providing top-notch service and gaining word-of-mouth recommendations, but marketing is an essential step to finding business before reaching that phase. Managers put their word out in trade and business publications in addition to securing industry sponsorships.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor intensity is high in this industry, as human employees are required to provide effective customer service. Although, the simpler functions of the job are becoming increasingly automated.

volatility_points.volatility_title: FLUCTUATING DISPOSABLE INCOMES AND RESIDENTIAL HOUSING PRICES HAVE INCREASED REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: While household disposable incomes and residential housing prices have risen over the past five years, annual changes have been volatile. These same fluctuations caused some tenants to be unable to pay rent during COVID-19, leading to temporary rent reduction agreements and eviction moratoriums.

volatility_points.volatility_title: RISING RESIDENTIAL HOUSING PRICES ARE PRICING BUYERS OUT OF THE MARKET
volatility_points.volatility_description: Residential housing prices are rising, discouraging potential buyers from purchasing properties. So rent prices have increased, as lower mortgage affordability and greater house prices have necessitated hikes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Residential property managers are often independent owner-operators with small-scale portfolios and do not benefit significantly from economies of scale. These managers do not tend to benefit significantly from investing in new technologies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: INVESTMENT REAL ESTATE (IRE) SOFTWARE SYSTEMS PROVIDE OPERATIONAL SUPPORT
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Residential property managers can pay subscription fees to use licensed IRE software systems. These systems have sophisticated tools for processing transactions and analyzing industry conditions.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer services primarily to consumers or businesses?
FAQs.answer: Operators primarily work with businesses in professional services or residential markets.

FAQs.question: Are there segments of your business that increase demand when economic growth is slow?
FAQs.answer: When economic growth is slow the industry benefits from consumers from residential markets, as rental vacancy rates decline.

FAQs.question: How do you contend with volatility in demand for commercial real estate?
FAQs.answer: Operators regularly researching market trends, tenant needs, and potential economic shifts helps anticipate changes in demand and adjust strategies accordingly.

FAQs.question: How has your company coped with rising wage costs over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the industry have relatively coped with rising wage costs by outsourcing, but revenue growth has consistently outpaced wage growth in this industry, leading to healthy profit margins.

FAQs.question: Have you successfully cut wage costs through automation in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have been minimized through the adaptation of outsourcing certain obligations. Additionally, advancement in technology has enabled operators to automate repetitive tasks for employees, which saves on wage costs.

FAQs.question: How much does your company spend on new technology annually? How does this compare with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: In this industry, technology is mainly used to manage back-office functions. As a result, most operators do not spend much on new technology.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure your properties are up to code?
FAQs.answer: Industry participants make sure properties are up to code by following both federal and state guidelines.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared for new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the industry have become increasingly sensitive to environmental issues and strive to meet such standards.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit in this industry for operators is relatively high compared to other industries.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: One of the biggest financing challenges for operators in this industry involve wage costs. As wages continue to tick higher across the economy, industry operators must pay a premium to retain skilled workers.

FAQs.question: How can you improve your staff's communication skills?
FAQs.answer: Property managers often serve as the liaison between owners and tenants, and must be able to communicate quickly and professionally. As a result, communication is important. This leads operators to focus on professional development for employees through increasing communication skills.

FAQs.question: How does your company differentiate itself from its competitors? How often does your company's strategic plan get reviewed?
FAQs.answer: The property management industry is highly fragmented, so it is important to have a strategic plan to differentiate property management businesses from competitors. Industry operators tend to focus on specific types of properties within a given sector or industry.

FAQs.question: What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area? Do you have a competitive pricing strategy?
FAQs.answer: Property managers must be in markets where there is ample demand for real estate services. Densely populated areas or places with strong population growth tend to be key markets for industry participants.

FAQs.question: How does the rental vacancy rate affect demand for your services? When the rate is high, how do you prepare?
FAQs.answer: When the residential vacancy rate is high, industry demand falls, and vice versa. Since home prices and consumer income levels influence residential rental vacancy rates, consumers tend to rent rather than buy homes when consumers have less disposable income or when the price of homeownership is high.

FAQs.question: How do you track trends in homeownership? How have you adjusted your rates during times of low homeownership?
FAQs.answer: As the homeownership rate rises, demand for industry services generally declines, since the majority of industry revenue is associated with residential rental property management services.

FAQs.question: How does a rise in office rental vacancy affect your company?
FAQs.answer: A high office rental vacancy rate indicates a large amount of unused commercial space and low industry demand. Although, having some empty properties helps maintain the value of the total portfolio.
